unit: Unit 23: The Rise of A Costume Salesman
question: How is Justin’s role in the community described? A) A tiresome hardware worker. B) A unique costume salesman. C) An alert fire-arms inspector. D) A community member who hates suggestions.

What challenge did Justin face during the Halloween season? A) An empire of ruined cookies. B) A customer who left a costume in ruins and complained. C) A tiresome inspection of the community center. D) A lack of confidence in his unique costumes.

Instead of offering an "apology," what did the customer do? A) Offered a suggestion for improvement. B) Provided an alert to the empire. C) Complained and blamed the costume’s quality. D) Asked for a relaxation of the rules.

How did Justin demonstrate "confidence" in his products? A) By ferrying the customer to another store. B) By offering a tiresome discount. C) By apologizing for the ruins. D) By performing a personal inspection and cramming into the costume.

What was the outcome of Justin’s demonstration? A) The costume was found to be in ruins. B) The costume remained intact, proving its quality. C) The community center sent an alert. D) Justin offered an apology to the hardware store.

How did the "unique" service impact Justin's business? A) It made his job more tiresome. B) Word spread, prompting a growth in customers. C) It led to the ruin of his community standing. D) He had to start ferrying costumes to the empire.
Justin’s business eventually grew into a what? A) A hardware store amidst the ruins. B) A costume empire. C) A tiresome community service. D) A unique suggestion box.

What "loyal" service did Justin provide to his customers? A) Ferrying them from what they needed to what they wore. B) Providing fire-arms for protection. C) Cramming their cookies into a hardware box. D) Suggesting they seek relaxation elsewhere.

Which local businesses did Justin’s sales outperform? A) The relaxation spa and cookie shop. B) The community library and hardware depot. C) The hardware store and the fire-arms store. D) The unique empire and the suggestion center.

Why did Justin give away "ginger cookies" in his store? A) Because he was in financial ruin. B) To improve the community's hardware. C) As a part of his commitment to customer satisfaction. D) To prompt the customer to give an apology.

What is Justin's advice for a thriving business? A) To always be alert and dedicated with some relaxation. B) To avoid unique suggestions. C) To cram as many costumes into the empire as possible. D) To perform tiresome inspections daily.

The word "amidst" in the story is used to describe: A) Justin’s position between the ruins. B) The location of the ginger cookies. C) The busy Halloween season environment. D) The hardware store's location.

What does "cramming" into the costume signify? A) Justin was too big for his own salesman job. B) Justin was willing to test his products under extreme pressure. C) The costume was in ruins before the test. D) The customer was unique in their request.

Justin "never found his job tiresome," which means: A) He was always alert and enjoyed his work. B) He spent all his time in relaxation. C) He hated the community empire. D) He only liked the hardware part of the job.
The customer "spread the word" because: A) Justin offered a tiresome apology. B) Justin went above and beyond with his service. C) The empire was in ruins. D) The ginger cookies were too unique.

What was the "suggestion" Justin typically gave? A) To buy fire-arms from the empire. B) To help customers find the perfect costume. C) To visit the hardware store for relaxation. D) To offer an apology for the ruins.
The term "empire" in this context refers to: A) A historical government. B) Justin's successful and extensive business. C) The community's hardware department. D) A tiresome collection of costumes.

Justin’s "alert" nature helped him: A) Identify danger signs in his shop. B) Perform tiresome inspections on the community. C) Find unique ginger cookies in the ruins. D) Ferry hardware to the salesman.

What was the "satisfaction" Justin prioritized? A) His own relaxation and cookies. B) Making the customer feel valued and heard. C) Building a tiresome hardware store. D) Getting an apology from the empire.

The "ruins" mentioned in the story specifically refer to: A) The state of the community after Halloween. B) The damaged condition of a costume. C) The decline of the fire-arms store. D) Justin’s initial financial status.

1: How does Ethan’s choice to pursue "organic gardening" at night reflect his "ambitious" nature?A) It demonstrates a preference for recreational activities over hard work.B) It shows he is avoiding the physical demands of construction sites.C) It indicates a lack of interest in traditional civilization.D) It highlights his dedication to obtaining diverse outcomes through multiple disciplines.

2: In the context of the article, what is the "absolute" goal Ethan strives toward?A) To gain insurance for his abdomen injury.B) To accomplish great things and arouse inspiration in his community.C) To restore the local graveyard to its former glory.D) To use a cunning plan to avoid manual labor.

3: When Ethan faces challenges, he chooses to "cope" by doing what?A) Decreasing his worries and defending his dreams.B) Investing all his money in laboratory euipment.C) Plotting a way to escape from the construction site.D) Relying on a parachute to escape his difficulties.

4: Why is the "manual labor" Ethan performs during the day strategically significant to his character arc?A) It shows he is incapable of intellectual pursuits like calculation.B) It represents the physical barrier he must restore.C) It establishes the distinct work ethic he uses to fuel his personal growth.D) It provides him the organic materials needed for his garden.

5: How does the article define the "outcome" of Ethan’s determination?A) He obtained a high-paying job at a local publisher.B) He successfully defended the village from a cunning fox.C) He became a pilot who used a parachute for recreation.D) He became a symbol of inspiration whose legacy reached beyond the horizon.

6: What motivated Ethan to "invest" his energy into obtaining new outcomes?A) A desire to open up a whole new world of personal growth.B) A fear of the local graveyard and the atmosphere of doubt.C) The need to pay for his medical insurance after an accident.D) A plan to seek revenge against his neighbors.

7: Which "characteristic" of Ethan’s mind is compared to a "parachute"?A) Its ability to decrease in size when under pressure.B) Its capacity to open up to a whole new world of possibilities.C) Its tendency to plot against the civilization.D) Its reliance on manual labor for support.

8: Ethan’s retreat to his "laboratory" or garden serves as a "shelter" from what?A) The physical injury to his abdomen.B) The need for book calculation at the publisher.C) The demands and stressors of everyday life.D) The distinct difference between organic and synthetic food.

9: What does the term "restore" imply regarding Ethan’s faith in himself?A) He needed to find a new goal after his injury.B) He had to obtain permission from the local authorities.C) He used manual labor to rebuild his home.D) He renewed his confidence to overcome an atmosphere of fear.

10: Ethan’s volunteer work at the "publisher" primarily involved what task?A) Assisting with book calculation and distribution.B) Defending the office against cunning competitors.C) Arousing excitement through organic marketing.D) Restoring the circulation of the local newspaper.

11: What is the strategic importance of the "horizon" in the story’s conclusion?A) It represents the limit of Ethan's manual labor.B) It symbolizes the vast reach of Ethan's inspiring legacy.C) It indicates the site of the local graveyard.D) It marks the boundary of the civilization he built.

12: How does Ethan "defend" his dreams against an "atmosphere of doubts"?A) Through aggressive confrontation with his peers.B) By obtaining a loan from a local bank.C) Through persistence and the use of strategic, sometimes cunning, plans.D) By decreasing the time he spends in his laboratory.

13: The injury to Ethan's "abdomen" is used in the narrative to demonstrate what?A) His inability to accomplish his goals.B) The failure of his medical insurance.C) The poor safety standards of the construction site.D) A setback that failed to deter his ultimate ambition.

14: Ethan believes a "civilization" thrives most when its members do what?A) Support and uplift one another in their pursuits.B) Compete fiercely to obtain the best outcomes.C) Invest only in manual and industrial labor.D) Avoid dozing off during recreation.

15: What "aroused" inspiration in Ethan's community?A) The cunning nature of his business deals.B) The combination of his hard work and eventual success.C) His ability to cope with blood circulation issues.D) The absolute silence he maintained in his garden.

16: Ethan’s "recreation" is described as vital because it allowed him to:A) Plot against his enemies in the graveyard.B) Parachute into new territories.C) Recharge and maintain healthy blood circulation.D) Manualize his organic gardening techniues.

17: Why does the author use the word "distinct" to describe Ethan?A) He was the only person in the village who liked gardening.B) He had a uniue abdomen injury that surgeons couldn't fix.C) He was an immigrant who didn't fit into the civilization.D) He possessed a uniue personality and set of ambitions compared to others.

18: Ethan’s spirit soaring beyond his "grave" is a metaphor for:A) The lasting impact of his determination on future generations.B) His desire for revenge against those who doubted him.C) His success in the publishing industry.D) His final outcome in the laboratory.

19: "Cunning" is used in the text to describe Ethan's plans. What does this suggest?A) Ethan was a dishonest person who tricked his neighbors.B) Ethan was resourceful and used clever strategies to protect his goals.C) Ethan was a pioneer in the field of animal psychology.D) Ethan intended to bankrupt the local publisher.

20: What was the "outcome" of Ethan's dedication to his work at the local publisher?A) He obtained a medal of honor from the embassy.B) He was able to restore the health of the local children.C) He gained respect and contributed to the success of the civilization.D) He realized his ambition was a mere distraction.

1: How did Dr. James' "luxurious" lifestyle impact his financial management?A) It forced him to become a pioneer in banking.B) It led him to occasionally rely on bank loans to fund his shopping.C) It convinced the university to increase his salary.D) It had no conseuence on his personal savings.

2: What was the primary "conseuence" of Dr. James' influence on the university?A) The institution had to reform its psychological department.B) He was forced to resign due to his luxurious habits.C) The students were uninspired by his innovative methods.D) The university experienced a significant surge in enrollment.

3: Dr. James is described as "influential" primarily because of what?A) His productive research and innovative teaching methods.B) His ability to bargain for rare antiue bracelets.C) His tendency to use profanity in the classroom.D) His luxurious mansion and expensive cars.

4: When Dr. James "bargained" for the antiue bracelet, what was the "intention" behind his purchase?A) To invest the item in a local museum.B) To sell it for a profit to a pioneer in the field.C) To add it to his collection of impulsive purchases.D) To use it as an ingredient in a psychological experiment.

5: What does the "volcano" metaphor describe in the context of the article?A) Dr. James' temper when students were unproductive.B) The rapid and powerful spread of his book's content.C) The luxurious nature of his expensive cars.D) The unstable nature of the university's economy.

6: How does Dr. James "convince" his students during his lectures?A) Through the use of aggressive rhetoric and shouting.B) By sharing secrets from his luxurious personal life.C) By promising them high salaries after graduation.D) Through his informative content and engaging delivery.

7: Dr. James believes that the "key ingredient" for influential change is:A) Having a large bank loan and a luxurious home.B) Being a pioneer in the field of antiue preservation.C) Having both knowledge and the right intention.D) Using the word "damn" to get students' attention.

8: In the text, what "tendency" did Dr. James’ students develop?A) A tendency to procrastinate on productive tasks.B) A tendency to strive for greatness in their respective fields.C) A tendency to spend money on expensive bracelets.D) A tendency to ignore the contents of his book.

9: Why is Dr. James considered a "pioneer" by his students?A) He was the first person to explore the local flea market.B) He established a new university in a volcanic region.C) He led the way in groundbreaking psychological research.D) He discovered the secret to a luxurious lifestyle.

10: The word "blend" is used to describe how the bracelet entered Dr. James' life. What does this suggest?A) He used a blender to destroy the antiue.B) He mixed the bracelet with his other psychological tools.C) He was ashamed of the purchase and hid it.D) The item naturally became a part of his everyday existence.

11: What "reform" did Dr. James believe education could bring to society?A) A complete overhaul of the social and academic systems.B) The elimination of all bank loans and luxurious goods.C) The preservation of all antiue flea markets.D) The increase of productive manual labor.

12: Why did Dr. James write "The Power of Words: A Guide to Success"?A) To bargain for a higher status at the university.B) To summarize his teachings for aspiring individuals.C) To explain the conseuence of buying rare bracelets.D) To complain about his students' tendencies.
13: Which "adjective" does the author claim is the only one fit for Dr. James?A) Lousy.B) Groundbreaking.C) Conservative.D) Timid.

14: What "not-so-good" habit did Dr. James possess?A) He was an amateur at psychology.B) He lacked the ability to inspire his students.C) He was a pioneer of volcanic research.D) He had an impulsive habit of buying things.

15: How did Dr. James handle the "challenges" of academia?A) He chose to resign and live in his mansion.B) He used his wealth to buy influence in the congress.C) He endured them and continued his productive work.D) He ignored them and focused on his luxurious cars.

16: What was the "content" of Dr. James’ book compared to?A) A mere distraction for sophomores.B) A luxurious gift for his colleagues.C) A rare antiue with good preservation.D) An erupting volcano of influence.

17: Dr. James’ use of "damn" in class is described as:A) A necessary ingredient for a productive lecture.B) An inappropriate but ultimately overshadowed habit.C) A cunning plan to convince his students.D) A groundbreaking reform in academic language.

18: What was Dr. James' "intention" when he went to the flea market?A) To find a rare antiue bracelet for his wife.B) To meet a pioneer who could reform his teaching.C) To purchase a loan from the bank.D) To buy some grapefruits.

19: The university enrollment surged as a "conseuence" of:A) The luxurious amenities offered in the dormitories.B) The rare antiues Dr. James displayed in his office.C) The low price of grapefruits in the local market.D) Dr. James' significant reputation and influence.

20: How did Dr. James’ students view him?A) As a lousy lecturer who used too much profanity.B) As a conservative figure who resisted change.C) As an idol and a source of professional inspiration.D) As an amateur who was lucky to have a luxurious life.

1: The philosopher’s library is described as "functional." What does this imply about his work?A) It was filled with identical books that served no purpose.B) It was enormous and luxurious, designed for status.C) It was practical and designed to support his pursuit of knowledge.D) It was enclosed and terrified the village children.

2: What did the philosopher "assure and concrete" through his actions?A) His unwavering devotion to the pursuit of knowledge.B) His status as the wealthiest man in the village.C) His plan to take over the local capitalism system.D) His identification of the student as a genius.

3: Why did the young examinee approach the philosopher?A) He wanted to run an errand for the elderly man.B) He was looking for a locker to store his belongings.C) He sought guidance on the adjustments needed in his study of economics.D) He wanted to confess that he had scratched the philosopher’s chair.
4: The student struggled with the "identification" of which economic system?A) Socialism.B) Capitalism.C) Feudalism.D) Industrialism.

5: What did the philosopher keep in his "locker"?A) His luxurious collection of antiue bracelets.B) Identical copies of his own biography.C) His most treasured presentations of thoughts and ideas.D) Secret documents about the village council.

6: The philosopher provided the student with a "rhythm of thoughts." What was the strategic goal?A) To help the student memorize nouns for his exam.B) To lead the student to a surrender of his preconceived notions.C) To terrify the student into working harder.D) To encourage the student to pursue a luxurious life.

7: How did the student’s mindset change after the meeting?A) He became terrified of the unknown and decided to stay home.B) He decided to explore identical thoughts elsewhere.C) He was no longer terrified but excited to explore new possibilities.D) He felt the philosopher’s advice was a mere distraction.

8: The term "fertile mind" used at the end of the article suggests that the student:A) Was now ready to grow and make a positive impact.B) Was confused by the philosopher’s presentation.C) Intended to become a manual laborer in a garden.D) Was obsessed with the creation of identical wealth.

9: What was the student’s "errand" after leaving the philosopher?A) To buy groceries for the village elders.B) To scratch the surface of economics in another town.C) To shape his own future and apply his new knowledge.D) To surrender his diploma to the university.

10: The article suggests that "identical thoughts" are a sign of:A) A functional and prosperous civilization.B) A lack of innovation and a failure to challenge the status uo.C) A concrete understanding of capitalism.D) A fertile and productive academic environment.

11: What does the philosopher do to the "surface of great ideas"?A) He encloses them in a locker.B) He scratches them, symbolizing a preliminary but insightful exploration.C) He surrenders them to the examinee.D) He assures them through manual labor.

12: The student’s "frustration" was primarily caused by:A) The philosopher’s refusal to give him money.B) His inability to understand the creation of wealth.C) The identical nature of the village's capitalism.D) Having to run errands in the heat of the day.

13: Why is the word "surrender" used in a positive sense in this narrative?A) It means the student gave up on his education.B) It refers to the student letting go of limiting, old ideas.C) It describes the philosopher surrendering his library.D) It indicates the village surrendering to capitalism.

14: What "adjustment" did the student ultimately make?A) He changed his major from economics to philosophy.B) He moved to a bigger city to find a luxurious life.C) He changed his perspective and approach to learning.D) He learned to copy the identical thoughts of the philosopher.

15: The philosopher "confessed" to devoting his life to what?A) The identification of rare minerals.B) The pursuit of knowledge.C) The creation of a functional empire.D) Running errands for the university.

16: How does the article define the "creation of wealth"?A) As a simple task that reuires no adjustment.B) As a complex concept the examinee initially struggled to grasp.C) As the only goal of a fertile mind.D) As an errand that everyone in the village must perform.

17: What does "enclosed" refer to in the first paragraph?A) The student’s mind before he met the philosopher.B) The philosopher’s thoughts within his library walls.C) The village’s conservative economic system.D) The locker where the treasured presentations were kept.

18: Why was the student "terrified" initially?A) He was afraid of the philosopher’s reputation.B) He feared the unknown challenges of his future.C) He was worried about failing his economics exam.D) He saw a ghost in the philosopher’s library.

19: The philosopher "assured and concreted" his devotion. What does this mean?A) He built a library out of cement.B) He promised the village he would never leave.C) He gave a presentation on capitalism.D) He made his commitment to learning firm and undeniable.

20: The "rhythm of thoughts" provided by the philosopher is a metaphor for:A) A repetitive and tiresome lecture.B) A structured and harmonious way of thinking.C) An identical set of rules for capitalism.D) A musical performance used to amuse the village.

1: Why was Alice’s life initially described as "miserable"?A) She was an immigrant who couldn't find manual labor.B) She was timid, filled with anxiety, and struggled to find her place.C) She was ashamed of her failure in the physics lab.D) She was being scolded for running too many errands.

2: What "disadvantage" did Alice believe she had to overcome?A) Her lack of finance for her university studies.B) Her timid nature and tendency to hide from social situations.C) Her inability to understand the rhythm of capitalism.D) Her lack of euipment for the research project.

3: How did Alice’s fellow students react when she offered to "contribute" to the project?A) They insulted her and scolded her for being uiet.B) They welcomed her with open arms and became acuaintances.C) They ignored her and continued their own sketch.D) They asked her to finance the group's research.
4: The group’s brainstorming session is compared to the sound of what?A) A landslide of applause.B) A chorus of birds.C) A harmonica.D) A volcanic eruption.

5: How did the team handle "mischief" and "obstacles"?A) With frustration and identical thoughts.B) With tolerance and collective dedication.C) By scolding the members who made mistakes.D) By surrendering to the research establishment.

6: What "climax" of excitement did the group reach?A) The moment they were scolded by the lecturer.B) The celebration of their success over alcohol.C) The purchase of a new backpack for Alice.D) The identification of a new species in the lab.

7: Why did the "research establishment" offer to "finance" the group?A) Because Alice was a timid and miserable girl.B) Because they were impressed by the group’s successful findings.C) Because the village council went bankrupt.D) Because the physicists needed new euipment.

8: Alice’s purchase of a "backpack" while using an "escalator" symbolizes:A) Her return to a life of manual labor.B) Her personal reward and reflection on her upward journey.C) Her desire to become a salesperson in the department store.D) Her need to carry heavy books for her errands.

9: What does it mean that Alice learned to "sway" the opinions of others?A) She used physical force to move them.B) She used her success and hard work to influence their perceptions.C) She used a cunning plan to trick the physicists.D) She used a harmonica to distract the lecturer.

10: How did Alice "rebel" against societal expectations?A) By scolding her parents for their lack of support.B) By becoming a wizard who performed magic tricks.C) By overcoming her timid nature and succeeding as an intellectual.D) By refusing to contribute to the research establishment.

11: The room’s applause is compared to a "landslide." What does this suggest about the audience’s reaction?A) It was dangerous and terrified the students.B) It was overwhelming and represented a massive victory.C) It was a mere distraction from the research.D) It was a sign of frustration with the presentation.

12: Why is Alice described as a "legend" and a "wizard" at the end?A) She learned how to perform magic for the department store.B) She achieved high status and expertise in her field.C) She moved to a luxurious castle in a fantasy world.D) She became the CEO of the research establishment.

13: What strategic role did the "physicists" play in Alice’s journey?A) They scold her for her lack of calculation skills.B) They provided the finance for her luxurious lifestyle.C) They served as the expert panel that validated her hard work.D) They were the pioneers who taught her how to play the harmonica.

14: Alice’s "anxiety and confusion" were transformed into:A) Identity and identical thoughts.B) Confidence and professional recognition.C) Miserable frustration with capitalism.D) A cunning plan for revenge.

15: What was the "establishment" mentioned in the article?A) A department store where Alice bought her backpack.B) A research institution that supported Alice's work.C) A restaurant where the group had alcohol.D) The university where the lecturer worked.

16: What does the "sparkle" in Alice’s final realization refer to?A) The jewelry she bought at the counter.B) The light hitting the department store escalator.C) Her ability to shine and succeed despite cruelty and obstacles.D) The sparks coming from the physics lab euipment.

17: Why did Alice initially expect an "insult"?A) Because she had failed her previous research project.B) Because she was used to being scolded and marginalized.C) Because the other students were known for being cruel.D) Because she had no money to contribute.

18: Alice and her team are referred to as "intellectuals." Why is this significant?A) It shows they were only interested in abstract theories.B) It highlights their status as serious thinkers and researchers.C) It suggests they were arrogant toward the villagers.D) It means they spent all their time reading literature.

19: The "chorus of praise" refers to:A) The students singing together after the project.B) The collective and unanimous approval of Alice's work.C) The sound of the harmonica during the presentation.D) The lecture given by the instructor.

20: How did Alice’s parents "scold" her in the past?A) For failing her exams and having no ambition.B) For being too uiet and not participating socially.C) For spending too much money on luxurious goods.D) For wanting to become a physicist.

1: Why was Alex "ashamed" of his past actions?A) He failed to obtain a degree in music.B) His dismissal of a government alert led to a tragedy.C) He was caught trying to steal from a local school.D) He used an imitation of a famous artist’s work.

2: Alex’s decision to ignore the "alert" was based on what?A) His desire to protect his luxurious property.B) His belief that the warning was merely fiction.C) His plan to seek revenge against the firefighters.D) His need to finish a manual labor project.

3: What "tragedy" occurred because of the mudslide and acid rain?A) Alex lost his permanent home and all his savings.B) Five firefighters were nearly killed trying to save him.C) The village went bankrupt and had to close its doors.D) The local music school was completely destroyed.

4: How did Alex "convey" his inner turmoil after the tragedy?A) Through aggressive protests against the government.B) By writing a biography of the firefighters who saved him.C) By creating audio compositions that expressed his spiritual journey.D) By running errands for the new immigrants in the village.

5: What does it mean that Alex’s progress was "evidenced" by positive feedback?A) He received a high salary for his compositions.B) His listeners clearly showed their appreciation for his work.C) He was given a promotion to a local government official.D) He was no longer reuired to wear a backpack.

6: How did Alex "euip" himself for his new career?A) He bought expensive audio software with a bank loan.B) He learned new skills and techniues to enhance his art.C) He built a new laboratory in the village graveyard.D) He obtained a license to perform in the city.

7: The "twinkle" Alex saw in his listeners' eyes represents:A) The reflection of the laboratory lights.B) The satisfaction and emotional connection they felt.C) The frustration they had with his imitation music.D) The alert they were sending him about another mudslide.

8: Why did Alex decide to "volunteer" at the local music school?A) He was forced by the government as a penalty for the tragedy.B) He wanted to share his passion and give back to the community.C) He was looking for a way to get a promotion.D) He needed a permanent place to store his audio euipment.

9: Alex is compared to a "submarine." What does this metaphor suggest?A) He was afraid of the surface and stayed hidden.B) He explored the deep, complex layers of human emotion.C) He was a pioneer in underwater audio technology.D) He was sinking under the weight of his past mistakes.

10: What "characteristic" of Alex’s new music touched people's hearts?A) Its reliance on old imitations of classical composers.B) Its uniue and heartfelt emotional ualities.C) Its loud and aggressive alert-like rhythms.D) Its ability to restore the village’s financial status.

11: What was the "permanent scar" mentioned in the article?A) A physical injury Alex sustained during the mudslide.B) The emotional guilt and memory of his past mistake.C) The damage caused to the village graveyard.D) The mark left on his abdomen by the acid rain.

12: Why did Alex "frown upon" the initial announcement?A) He didn't like the tone of the local mayor.B) He was skeptical and didn't take the danger seriously.C) He wanted to stay and finish his audio composition.D) He thought the firefighters were being too aggressive.

13: The story of Alex is described as an "exhibit" of:A) Resilience and triumph over tragedy.B) The dangers of living in a volcanic region.C) The failure of local government alerts.D) A pursuit of a luxurious and selfish lifestyle.

14: How did Alex’s confidence "enlarge"?A) Through the help of a cunning career coach.B) Through consistent practice and positive reception of his art.C) By obtaining medical insurance for his spiritual journey.D) By moving to a more fertile and prosperous village.

15: What "satisfaction" did Alex find in his new life?A) He was finally able to afford a luxurious mansion.B) He found fulfillment in creating meaningful music.C) He received revenge against those who scolded him.D) He became the most influential immigrant in the country.

16: What was the "tragedy" mentioned at the end of the first paragraph?A) The loss of the village's cultural history.B) The severe injuries to the brave rescue workers.C) Alex’s refusal to pay for his medical recovery.D) The destruction of the local laboratory.

17: Why is Alex's "spiritual journey" mentioned?A) He decided to become a philosopher in the village.B) He was exploring deep personal growth through his art.C) He was looking for a way to restore the ancient tomb.D) He had a fantasy of traveling to another world.

18: What was the "outcome" of Alex’s work at the music school?A) He was asked to resign due to his past.B) He was recognized and offered a promotion.C) He became an amateur firefighter.D) He learned how to play the harmonica.

19: Alex "interacted" with a diverse group of people. Why was this important?A) It allowed him to sell his audio euipment.B) It helped him build a sense of community and connection.C) It convinced him to start a new capitalism system.D) It gave him a reason to run errands for the village.

20: The final paragraph suggests that Alex's story:A) Is a cautionary tale about ignoring alerts.B) Serves as an inspiration for others to believe in themselves.C) Proves that immigrants should not live in mudslide zones.D) Is a mere fiction created for entertainment.

unit: Unit 29; The Rise of A Costume Salesman
question: 1: What "uniue" uality did Justin possess as a salesman?A) He had a cunning plan to trick the community.B) He was consistently dedicated to customer satisfaction.C) He was an amateur at costume design but lucky in business.D) He was the only person who liked ginger cookies.

2: Justin never found his job "tiresome." What does this suggest about his mindset?A) He was energetic and passionate about his profession.B) He was lazy and spent most of his time dozing off.C) He was a pioneer who didn't understand hard work.D) He found his work to be a mere distraction from his empire.

3: When the customer left a costume in "ruins," how did Justin strategically respond?A) He demanded an immediate apology and a bank loan.B) He used a cunning plan to blame the customer.C) He scold the customer in front of the community.D) He confidently performed an inspection to prove the uality.

4: Why did Justin "cram" himself into one of the costumes?A) He was trying to hide from the angry customer.B) He wanted to show off his physical fitness.C) He was demonstrating the durability and integrity of the product.D) He was preparing for a role in a local opera.

5: What was the "outcome" of Justin’s uniue approach to sales?A) He went bankrupt and had to close his doors.B) He built his own empire and became a local legend.C) He was forced to move his business elsewhere.D) He became an immigrant in a new community.

6: Why is the word "empire" used to describe Justin’s business?A) He ruled the community with aggressive arms.B) He built a large, successful, and influential organization.C) He lived in a luxurious palace made of costumes.D) He used the capitalism system to destroy his rivals.

10: What "alert" and "dedicated" behavior did Justin exhibit?A) He was always on the lookout for ways to scold his staff.B) He maintained a sharp focus on uality and service.C) He was alert to any signs of a mudslide.D) He was dedicated to collecting rare ginger.

19: Justin outperformed the "fire-arms" store. What does this symbolize?A) The community’s preference for creativity over conflict.B) Justin’s aggressive business tactics.C) The bankruptcy of the local government.D) The rise of a new volcanic eruption.

The use of the word "breeds" to describe different types of AI suggests: A) AI systems are biological in nature. B) There are diverse varieties of AI applications. C) AI is a conservative species of technology. D) AI is primarily used for animal breeding.

How do AI drones assist in rescue operations according to the narrative logic? A) By conversing with minerals to locate debris. B) By spearing through debris using sensors. C) By acting as faithful messengers for seniors. D) By registering the survivors at the hospital.

The term "dynamic landscape" in the conclusion suggests that the future of AI is: A) Severe and stationary. B) Constantly evolving and progressing. C) Limited to the field of scenery and art. D) Only beneficial to senior citizens.

Which of the following is an inference supported by the medical section? A) AI is currently the only tool used for surgeries. B) Hospitals ignore the merit of AI for senior care. C) Surgeons have a hesitation to use any AI sensors. D) AI-assisted operations result in faster patient recovery.

How does AI "guarantee" safety in emergency response? A) By providing a robotic alternative in hazardous zones. B) By sending telegrams to all needy families. C) By identifying minerals without any gaze. D) By sculptures that help survivors glide.

The "true potential" of AI was realized when: A) It became an overnight success in the scenery industry. B) Different breeds of AI came into our gaze recently. C) It replaced the faithful dog in the workplace. D) It stopped analyzing radioactive minerals.

The use of AI for survivors in the rubble implies that: A) AI can converse to provide a psychological connection. B) AI will use a drill to destroy the survivors' scenery. C) AI is a conservative tool for medical registration. D) survivors prefer sculptures to rescue operations.

"Embracing its benefits" suggests a society that: A) Recognizes the merit of technology while regulating it. B) Replaces all senior citizens with robotic drills. C) Hesitates to use any gigantic leap in progress. D) Guarantees that AI will cease all operations.

The article's tone regarding the future "scenery" of AI is: A) Pessimistic and severe. B) Optimistic and focused on transformation. C) Conservative and faithful to the past. D) Needy and requiring immediate rescue.

Why is the "gigantic leap" described as happening "in recent years"? A) Because the concept was only invented last week. B) Because AI has finally replaced the senior doctor. C) Because the potential of various AI breeds has emerged. D) Because the registration for surgeries became a blessing.

Mark feared that being passive would inevitably lead to: A) Success and literature B) Contentment and grace C) Isolation and neglect D) Negotiating a settlement

Why did Mark cherish connections with literary characters more than real people? A) Because real people were too passive. B) Because he preferred nouns to verbs. C) Because his pessimistic outlook caused a disconnect. D) Because he wanted to negotiate with history.

In the new world, Mark stopped contesting for status because: A) He was too busy drinking syrup. B) The people were kind and welcoming. C) He had disconnected from his heart. D) He was in a state of neglect.

What was Mark’s specific "resolve" upon returning to his world? A) To put a cease to his selfishness. B) To build a new tomb site. C) To split more wood for artifacts. D) To neglect his connections with others.

What does the word "split" describe in the climax of the story? A) Mark’s personality during the conflict. B) The way the tomb walls opened. C) The disconnection from Mark’s friends. D) The way Mark ate the syrup.

Why did Mark's heart "race with excitement"? A) Because he was aggressive. B) Because he was about to enter a new world. C) Because he forgot his literature. D) Because he was neglected.

Emily’s "guilty secret" involves her private: A) Reputation in a neighboring town B) Contentment in collecting fragrances C) Refusal to work on assignments D) Embarrassment over her profession

Emily's decision to accept the offer was made after: A) A reflection of her heart. B) Careful consideration. C) A guilty assignment. D) A leisurely stroll.

The "reflection" Emily finds in fragrances is primarily: A) A physical mirror image. B) A manifestation of her deep love and identity. C) A technical byproduct of intensive research. D) A way to route her toward the boutique.

In the context of the story, "equality" refers to: A) The pace of the river's flow. B) Shared social justice and responsibility. C) The amount of grass mown by Emily. D) The critical remarks in the book.

unit: Unit 36: Love Blossoms at the Library
question: 1. According to the text, what characterizes the architectural design of the local library? A) A modern oval-shaped design B) A traditional Victorian structure C) A solar-powered skyscraper D) A historical rectangular cottage

2. What is Oliver’s primary technical responsibility at the library? A) Managing the archival database B) Maintaining the power supply C) Repairing the wooden bookshelves D) Enforcing the monthly membership fees

8. Where did Oliver and Emily go for their first date? A) A local museum of ancient dynasties B) The modern oval library lounge C) A mountainous village nearby D) A cozy café

9. In the sentence, "the conventional rules were still in place," the word "conventional" most nearly means: A) Traditional or customary B) Extremely difficult C) Recently implemented D) Unnecessarily harsh
10. When Oliver is required to enforce the quiet policy, he is: A) Changing the regulations B) Ensuring the rules are followed C) Ignoring the rules for friends D) Writing new library laws
11. Emily’s access to the latest novels is described as occurring: A) Daily B) Weekly C) Monthly D) Yearly
12. The term loyalty in the context of the story refers to Emily's: A) Dedication to her math studies B) Commitment to the electrician C) Obedience to her parents D) Faithful enthusiasm for books
13. The word crush describes Oliver’s: A) Physical injury from a falling book B) Romantic infatuation with Emily C) Method of processing walnut shells D) Reaction to the library's design

14. In the phrase "with obedience to his heart," the word "obedience" suggests: A) Fear of breaking library rules B) Compliance with a higher authority C) Submitting to internal feelings D) Following a professional procedure

15. How does Oliver’s role as an electrician parallel his romantic development? A) Both require him to be a "witness" to technical failures B) Neither role allows him to be "flexible" with rules C) Both involve managing "power" (electrical vs. emotional) D) He flunks both roles before achieving a "triumph"

16. What does the "spear" metaphor reveal about the power of literature in this unit? A) It suggests stories are "offensive" to the reader's peace B) It implies that books are a "grave" distraction C) It shows literature can be "troublesome" for students D) It emphasizes the sharp, effective impact of art on grief

17. Which detail best supports the idea that the library is a site of "rigid order"? A) The enforcement of a quiet policy B) The presence of a solar-powered system C) The availability of walnut lattes D) The monthly access to new novels

18. What does Emily’s "imagined bridegroom" suggest about her reading experience? A) She is "nearsighted" and confused by the plot B) She is deeply engrossed and emotionally invested C) She is looking for a "respectable" real-life husband D) She is "vain" and only cares about the characters' looks

19. How does Oliver demonstrate "courtesy" toward Emily? A) By allowing her to skip the library entrance fee B) By helping her study for her math retake C) By recommending a book to alleviate her sadness D) By fixing her digital camera equipment

20. What is the symbolic significance of the "walnut lattes" and "elastic hair tie"? A) They represent the "daily grind" of the characters B) They show the library is a "fossil" of the past C) They indicate "economic" hardship for the couple D) They signal the transition from formal rules to personal intimacy

unit: Unit 37:  Photographer Discovers Passion in Underwater World
question: 1. What was Emily’s status at the beginning of the story? A) A junior high school student B) A professional digital mechanic C) A senior researcher in marine biology D) An accountant for a mountainous village
2. Where did Emily live before her expedition? A) A modern city with solar power B) A mountainous village C) A submarine research station D) A prestigious university campus
